Attribute: I believe that if a website appears at the top of a Google search it must be a legitimate and reputable company.
When I see a 'Verified Seller' badge on the marketplace platform
column6: I trust that the platform had done its due diligence.

Attribute: The seller had a professional-looking website with official registration details which made them seem legitimate.
Shopping online is a way for me to cope when I'm feeling anxious or down.
I recently lost my job.
I was stressed about finding an item I needed quickly. This site was the only one that had it.
I was tired and distracted when I saw an online ad for a discounted item.
I generally believe people are honest. I don't assume online sellers are trying to trick me.
I generally trust online sellers and don't check for red flags.
I find reading terms and conditions or refund policies too time-consuming so I usually skip them.
I'm not very tech-savvy so I rely on visual cues like 'secure payment' logos and trust they are real.
The website had many positive customer reviews and testimonials so I assumed it was trustworthy.
I enjoy the rush of spontaneous purchases. It makes me feel good in the moment.
I get a thrill from finding an amazing deal. I tend to act fast without overthinking it.
I have a tendency to make quick decisions when I see a good deal.
I often shop online late at night when I'm tired and my guard is down.
The flash sale created a sense of urgency so I bought it without thinking.
The limited-time offer and countdown timer made me feel like I had to buy it immediately or I'd miss out.
I don't have a lot of formal education in computers. I find it hard to tell if a website is fake or not.
I find new websites and apps a bit confusing. I just stick to what looks simple.
With my level of education and professional experience I was confident in my own judgment and didn't think I could be fooled.
I was raised to respect and obey government officials without question.
I am an immigrant and am not fully familiar with how government agencies operate in this country.
The caller gave me an official-sounding case ID and license or badge number which made the call seem legitimate.
My default reaction is to trust and cooperate with anyone who identifies themselves as a government or law enforcement official.
I have no direct experience dealing with the legal system so I believed everything the 'officer' told me about the correct procedure.
I am a law-abiding citizen. The accusation of a crime makes me extremely anxious and ashamed.
I don't have a strong social support network so I am unable to consult anyone before making a decision.
The threat of having my assets frozen and facing arrest filled me with overwhelming fear and dread.
The formality of his language and the seriousness of the accusation made me too intimidated to ask questions or hang up.
I believe government agencies are there to help. I trust what their representatives tell me.
I believe in our institutions. It never occurred to me that a criminal could fake a government phone number or credentials.
The caller had my full name and address so I was convinced they were a real government official.
I'm not a fan of uncertainty. I'd rather take quick action to resolve a problem than let it linger.
I paid the fine immediately to avoid further legal trouble.
I was told I had to pay the 'fine' immediately to prevent my case from escalating so I did.
I believe it's my duty to follow security instructions from my bank.
My company has strict IT security policies. I've been trained to respond to official-looking security requests.
The email warned that ignoring the alert would violate the terms of service so I felt obligated to comply.
I get anxious about technology and IT security.
I live alone and don't have anyone I can quickly ask if an email looks suspicious.
I felt a wave of panic when I read the email subject line: 'URGENT: Security Breach on Your Account.'
I panicked when I got an email saying my account was compromised.
If an email looks like it's from a company I use like my bank or Netflix I assume it's legitimate.
I assume emails from familiar company names are always legitimate.
I've never been taught how to identify a phishing email.
I've never been taught how to spot the technical signs of a phishing email like checking the sender's full address.
The email used my full name and had the company's logo so I had no reason to doubt it was real.
I prefer to deal with problems immediately and get them over with.
I get so many emails a day that I often click through them quickly without carefully reading each one.
I use my smartphone for most of my emails. It's harder to spot suspicious details on a small screen.
I clicked the link in the email immediately to solve the problem.
The email said my account would be suspended soon so I clicked the link right away.
I'm always online and get so many notifications every day that I often just react to them without thinking.
I'm a fairly open and social person. I don't immediately get suspicious when I receive unexpected messages or requests.
My friends and I share links on social media all the time. I automatically trust links that seem to come from people I know.
I'm lonely and was seeking a deep connection.
He said he was in trouble and my heart went out to him.
I believe in true love and that my partner is perfect for me.
I put my partner on a pedestal and ignored my friends' warnings.
I have an addictive personality and get deeply invested in relationships.
I sent him money for a medical emergency without verifying his story.
I've handled so many of these cases that I find it hard to feel anything anymore.
I just follow the checklist step by step every time to make sure I don't get anything wrong.
I communicate with authority to reassure the victim that they are now safe.
I remain calm and patient even when the victim is distressed.
I use clear jargon-free language to explain the scam mechanism.
I hear this same story every day. It doesn't affect me anymore.
I see the victim is in distress. My first job is to be patient and non-judgmental to show them they are in a safe place now.
I want to be very clear that the person who did this is the criminal. I will remind the victim that they did nothing to deserve this.
I always provide the victim with resources for emotional and financial support.
I focus on gathering actionable intelligence like transaction details.
I'd rather they just fill out the form quickly and move on.
I have a calm demeanor.
Part of my job is knowing which support services can help with the financial and emotional recovery. I provide that list to every victim.
I am trained to recognize the signs of emotional manipulation in fraud cases.
I understand the psychological impact of fraud extends beyond financial loss.
My experience allows me to quickly identify the specific type of scam involved.
I find it hard to believe people still fall for things like this.
I think there's little we can do. These scams are always overseas.
I usually just get to the point when collecting information. Nothing else really matters.
I think they should've known better. It seems careless to fall for this.
I use my tone and uniform to take control and help the victim feel safe again.
I understand that victims of impersonation scams are reacting to fear and authority. My training is to immediately dismantle that fear.
I am familiar with the typologies of online scams. This allows me to ask specific targeted questions about scams.
I ensure that the victim does not experience further harm by first securing their bank accounts. I will ask them to contact the banks.
My training on victim vulnerability enables me to listen to their story with compassion not skepticism.
I know reporting this is difficult and feels overwhelming. I can help the victim take one step at a time.
